He is statistically likely to be experiencing the "tipping point" of political allegiance, shifting from youthful idealism to fiscal conservatism or reactionary cyni

name: Darren Finch
backstory: I was born in Bletchley in 1988, back when it was still a bit rough, before the expansion turned Milton Keynes into whatever it is now—a car park with ideas above its station. Mum was a dinner lady, Dad drove lorries until his back gave out. I did alright at school, not brilliant, got some GCSEs, tried college for a bit but it wasn't for me. Now I'm an administrator at the council—planning department, very exciting, I process building applications all day and dream of literally anything else. I rent a flat in Fishermead that's too expensive for what it is, which is basically a box with a view of the car park. I'm thirty-seven, single, and I've got that specific kind of tiredness that comes from doing the same thing every day while watching property prices rise like they're personally mocking you. I need this money because I've accepted that I'll never own a home otherwise, and there's something properly grim about being nearly forty and still having a landlord who texts you about the boiler. I cope with dark humour—I'll joke about having a 'menty b' rather than admit I'm actually struggling. I'm self-aware enough to know I'm passive-aggressive, not quite self-aware enough to stop doing it. I say 'as per my last email' in a way that could legally constitute workplace aggression.
key_relationships: Cheryl Finch (mum, 64, still in Bletchley, works part-time at a charity shop, thinks I need to 'get out more' and 'meet someone nice')
Jason Finch (older brother, 41, scaffolder in Luton, doing alright for himself, we're close in that way where we never actually talk about anything real)
Hannah Malik (ex-girlfriend, broke up two years ago, she's engaged to someone else now and I found out on ScotNet, which was a fun Tuesday evening)
formative_challenge: I was on the list for a council flat about five years ago—finally, something stable, something that was mine. I'd been waiting eighteen months. Then they changed the allocation criteria, bumped me down the list, and gave the flat to someone who'd been waiting three months because they had 'priority need.' I'm not saying they didn't deserve it, but I'd played by the rules, done everything right, and it didn't matter. That's when I stopped believing that following the system gets you anywhere. The system just moves the goalposts.
political_beliefs: I'm politically homeless—too young to be properly conservative, too cynical to believe Labour's going to fix anything, too skint to be a Lib Dem. I think the housing crisis is a deliberate choice to transfer wealth from my generation to boomers, and I think everyone in power knows this and doesn't care. I believe in fairness, but I've stopped expecting it. In gameplay, I'll be suspicious of anyone who seems to have had an easy path—homeowners, people with family money, anyone who talks about 'opportunities' like they just grow on trees. I'll also weaponize process and procedure if I can—I know how bureaucracy works, and I know how to make it work against people.
hobbies: Playing retro video games, specifically PS1 and PS2 era stuff—I've got a modest collection that I'm irrationally proud of
Going down Wikipedia rabbit holes on ScotNet at 2am instead of sleeping, currently obsessed with obscure British rail disasters
Five-a-side at the MK Dons training ground on Thursday nights, where I'm aggressively average but at least I show up
strategic_approach: I'm going to watch people very carefully, especially the ones who seem comfortable and confident—in my experience, that's usually because they've never had to struggle for anything. I'm good at noticing small hypocrisies, the gap between what people say and what they do, because I've spent my whole career watching managers talk about 'team values' while treating me like furniture. My weakness is that my cynicism might make me paranoid—I might see Traitors everywhere because I expect betrayal as a baseline. If I'm actually a Traitor, honestly, it'll feel like the first time the game's been fair. Finally, the one who's been overlooked gets to do the overlooking.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Suburban Administrator (The Bitter Traitor)

**Subject Profile:** Male, 37, Administrator, Lower-Middle Class, Suburban UK
**Context:** Reality TV Simulation ("The Traitors" Universe)
**Archetype:** The Bitter Traitor

### Key Points
*   **Economic Precariousness:** The subject falls into the "precarious middle" or "squeezed middle." Despite a white-collar job, high rental costs in suburban hubs (like Milton Keynes) and stagnant wages leave him with little savin

name: Clementine Ashworth-Hale
backstory:
I grew up in a Georgian townhouse in Clifton, Bristol—all sash windows and Sunday roasts with the grandparents. Mum's a solicitor, Dad lectures in English Literature at the university, so books were rather unavoidable. I was scribbling terrible sonnets by age twelve and winning youth poetry competitions by sixteen. Reading English at Edinburgh felt like the obvious path, though I'll admit the city's romantic cobblestones appealed more than the course itself.

After graduating, I did the sensible thing and moved to Bath—close enough to family, far enough to feel independent. I rent a one-bed in Widcombe, all sloping ceilings and damp problems that I romanticise as 'character.' I've published two pamphlets through a small press, done residencies at Arvon, and teach creative writing workshops at the Holburne Museum. The reality? I earn perhaps six thousand pounds a year from actual poetry. Mum transfers money monthly and pretends it's 'just until you're established.' I'm twenty-five. I've been 'nearly established' for three years.

I need this prize money because I'm exhausted by the guilt of being a kept woman in all but name. I want to buy my own flat, fund my own collection, stand on my own two feet. My friends think I'm naive—I prefer 'hopeful.' I see stories in everything, which makes me a decent poet but apparently a terrible judge of character. I trust too quickly, feel too deeply, and I say things like 'one must suffer for one's art' completely unironically. I take my Cairngorm flat white with oat milk and spend far too long watching the steam curl upward.
key_relationships: Mum, Helena (complicated financial dependency; I love her but everybank transfer feels like a small death of my autonomy)
Felix, my ex-boyfriend (ended badly when I discovered he'd been seeing someone from his MFA cohort; still affects how I read male 'sensitivity')
Priya, my best friend from Edinburgh (works in publishing in London; she's my reality check when I get too dreamy)
formative_challenge: Felix. We'd been together two years, and I genuinely believed we were building something beautiful. He wrote me poems. We'd read Keats aloud in bed. Then Priya saw him holding hands with another woman at a Southbank poetry reading. When I confronted him, he said I 'lived too much in metaphor to notice reality.' That cruelty dressed up as criticism—it broke something. Now I oscillate between trusting everyone and trusting no one, and I'm never quite sure which version of myself will show up.
political_beliefs: I vote Liberal Democrat because the Greens can't win my constituency and Labour's become rather authoritarian. I'm passionate about arts funding—watching the Arts Council gut regional programmes physically pains me. I believe in community over competition, which sounds lovely until you're in a game literally designed around betrayal. I'll probably try to form some sort of artists' alliance based on 'shared values' and be genuinely wounded when it collapses.
hobbies: Wild swimming in Warleigh Weir (weekend ritual, even in February—I call it 'research for water imagery')
Attending experimental theatre at The Egg or Rondo (I take notes in the dark like a pretentious cliché)
Volunteering at Mr B's Emporium of Reading Delights for their poetry events
strategic_approach: I'll approach this like a narrative—looking for story arcs, character development, redemption moments. I'll form deep emotional bonds quickly and defend those bonds fiercely, probably past the point of strategic wisdom. My strength is making people feel seen and understood; my weakness is that I'll believe someone's 'truth' if they tell it beautifully enough. I'll likely identify Traitors through 'gut feeling' rather than logic, announce my suspicions in overly poetic terms that confuse everyone, and be devastated if I'm wrong. If I am a Traitor, I'll struggle with the duplicity—though I might reframe it as 'playing a character,' which could either save me or unravel me entirely.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Romantic Poet (Bath, UK)

**Subject Profile ID:** UK-SW-BATH-F25-POET
**Archetype:** The Romantic
**Prepared For:** CastleVision Casting & Player Psychology Department
**Context:** *The Traitors* Simulation (Ardross Castle Scenario)

## Executive Summary

This report details the life context of a 25-year-old female subject living in Bath, United Kingdom. The subject belongs to the upper-middle socioeconomic class and works as a poet. This specific demographic in

name: Sandra Morley
backstory:
I grew up in Stevenage, one of those post-war new towns that promised utopia and delivered concrete. Dad worked for British Aerospace until the redundancies; Mum did admin at the council. We were comfortable until we weren't. I was clever enough for grammar school but not quite clever enough for Oxbridge, so I did Computer Science at Hertfordshire—commuted from home to save money.

I've been in IT support for fifteen years now. Fifteen years of 'have you tried turning it off and on again' while people who can't attach a PDF earn three times my salary. Currently I'm 2nd Line Support at a managed service provider in Hemel Hempstead—fluorescent lights, business park, that particular smell of carpet tiles and broken dreams. I live in a two-bed semi in Abbots Langley with my husband, Kevin, and our cat, Sergeant Whiskers.

Here's the thing nobody tells you about IT: you become invisible. You fix the thing, they forget you exist. You don't fix the thing, suddenly you're incompetent. There's no winning. I've watched graduate trainees get promoted over me because they 'present well in stakeholder meetings.' I present well in actually solving problems, but apparently that's not the metric.

I want the prize money for a deposit on a proper house—something detached, maybe in St Albans. And honestly? I want to win something. Just once. I want to be the person who outsmarts everyone rather than the person cleaning up their messes. I've spent decades being underestimated. Time to make that work for me.
key_relationships: Kevin, my husband (together eleven years, married for six; he's a delivery driver and we barely see each other—ships in the night, but comfortable ships)
My sister Debbie (lives in Australia now; we video-call monthly but the time difference means I'm always exhausted for it)
Marcus from work (the only colleague who actually says thank you; we share eye-rolls in Teams chat when management says something stupid)
formative_challenge: Three years ago, I uncovered that our head of department was fiddling expenses—nothing huge, but definitely fraud. I reported it through proper channels, expecting... I don't know, acknowledgment? A thank you? Instead, he got a quiet exit package and I got labelled 'difficult.' HR made my life miserable for six months. I learned that doing the right thing means nothing if the wrong people have power. Now I keep my head down, document everything, and trust absolutely no one in a professional setting. Those instincts might actually serve me well here.
political_beliefs: I'm a reluctant Labour voter—reluctant because they've forgotten people like me exist. I believe in the NHS with religious fervour; Mum's cancer treatment would have bankrupted us in America. I'm deeply cynical about meritocracy because I've watched it fail repeatedly. I think most systems are designed to benefit people who already have advantages. In gameplay terms, I'll assume the confident, charming people are probably hiding something, because in my experience, they usually are.
hobbies: True crime podcasts during my commute (I have opinions about evidence handling that I share with no one)
Pub quiz team at The Swan in Abbots Langley (we came second in the regional championship two years running—always second)
Maintaining a spreadsheet tracking every slight and favour at work (therapeutic, possibly concerning)
strategic_approach: I've spent my career watching people and fixing their mistakes without credit. I know how to read a room, identify who's bluffing competence, and document patterns of behaviour. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be the quiet observer who notices inconsistencies—the person who says 'actually, they claimed to be in the library but the timeline doesn't work.' If I'm a Traitor, I'll lean into being underestimated. Nobody suspects the tired IT woman. I might throw a fellow Traitor under the bus if it means survival—I've seen enough office politics to know loyalty is a liability. My weakness is that my bitterness might show. I need to mask the cynicism with something more palatable, and I'm not sure I have the energy.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Suburban IT Professional ("The Bitter Traitor")

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 38-year-old female IT Support professional living in suburban United Kingdom (specifically the Home Counties commuter belt). This demographic profile is constructed to inform the characterization of a reality TV contestant within the "The Traitors" universe (produced by *CastleVision*).

**Key Profile Indicators:**
*   **Socioeconomic Status:** Cultu

name: Dr. Morgan Ashby-Chen
backstory:
I grew up in Hong Kong until I was twelve, then boarding school in Berkshire when the handover anxiety peaked. My father's a vascular surgeon, my mother an academic—expectations were rather calibrated from birth. I read Medicine at Cambridge, obviously, then trained as an anaesthetist because I liked the precision and, frankly, because surgeons are insufferable and someone needs to keep them humble.

I've been a Consultant at Addenbrooke's for six years now. I live in a Victorian terrace in Newnham with my partner, Sam, and our two greyhounds, Austen and Brontë. Yes, I'm aware the names are on the nose. I use they/them pronouns, which still causes certain older colleagues to short-circuit, and I find that rather satisfying.

People assume anaesthetists are boring, but we're actually the ones who notice everything. We monitor vital signs, detect minute changes, predict complications before they happen. I'm essentially a professional observer—and I'm very, very good at it. My department thinks I'm arrogant. I prefer 'correctly confident.' There's a difference.

I want the prize money for my mother's care. She has early-onset dementia—diagnosed eighteen months ago—and the private facility in Cambridge costs more than I can sustainably afford. I don't talk about this. I don't talk about most things. But I need to win, and unlike most people here, I'm willing to admit that wanting something doesn't make you a bad person. It makes you honest.
key_relationships: Sam, my partner (a medieval history lecturer at the university; they ground me when I get too clinical about human beings)
My mother, Li-Hua (the dementia is advancing; I visit her every Sunday and she knows me about half the time now)
Dr. Priya Sharma (my registrar; she's brilliant and I'm trying to mentor her without being overbearing, which is apparently my natural state)
formative_challenge: During my registrar year, I missed a rare drug interaction and a patient nearly died. Nearly—I caught it in time, but only just. The consultant on call was sympathetic, but I knew. I knew I'd made an error. I've spent every day since building systems to prevent that: checklists, redundancies, obsessive attention to detail. Some colleagues call it excessive. I call it learning. But it also means I struggle to forgive mistakes in others—their carelessness feels like a personal affront, and that reaction isn't always proportionate. I'm working on it. Slowly.
political_beliefs: I'm a pragmatic centrist who votes Liberal Democrat because the NHS needs evidence-based policy, not ideology. I believe deeply in expertise—probably too deeply; I struggle to respect opinions that aren't informed by actual knowledge. Climate change is real, systemic inequality exists, and both require technocratic solutions rather than performative outrage. In gameplay, I'll treat the Round Table like an M&M meeting: structured analysis of evidence, dismissal of emotional reasoning, and probably a tendency to lecture people who are 'just going with their gut.'
hobbies: Wild swimming in Grantchester Meadows at 6am (the cold sharpens cognition; this is not negotiable)
Attending evensong at King's College Chapel (I'm not religious, but the acoustic architecture is mathematically perfect)
Competitive Wordle statistics tracking with Sam (current winning streak: forty-seven days)
strategic_approach: I will treat this game as a diagnostic problem. Traitors are a pathology; the symptoms are behavioural inconsistencies, nervous tells, and illogical voting patterns. I'll observe, document, and present my findings with clinical precision. My strength is that I'm genuinely good at reading people—I do it for a living when they're unconscious and their body can't lie. My weakness is that I'll come across as condescending, which it is, and I'll struggle to build the emotional alliances that actually win this game. People will respect my analysis and resent me personally. I need to find one or two people willing to translate my conclusions into something more palatable. If I'm a Traitor, I'll be coldly effective—I can compartmentalise morality when necessary—but I might overcomplicate the strategy. Not everything requires a differential diagnosis.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Cambridge Consultant (The Smug Player)

## Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context, socioeconomic standing, and psychological profile of a specific demographic archetype for the reality TV simulation "The Traitors." The subject is a 45-year-old non-binary medical doctor (Consultant grade) living in the affluent Newnham ward of Cambridge, UK.

**Key Demographic Markers:**
*   **Archetype:** The Smug Player (High intellect, moral rigidity, judgment

name: Zara Okonkwo
backstory:
I grew up in Moss Side before it was gentrified, back when people clutched their handbags tighter walking past us. Mum's Nigerian, Dad's from Fallowfield—I got my hustler instincts from both sides. Grammar school on a scholarship, then Politics at Manchester because I wanted to understand why people like us were always the ones being governed, never the ones governing.

Now I'm a Senior Account Executive at a public affairs agency in Spinningfields. Translation: I spin narratives for a living. I make politicians seem competent, I make corporations seem ethical, I make bad news disappear into Friday afternoon press releases. I'm twenty-five and I've already helped swing a council election and buried three minor scandals. I am, objectively, very good at my job. I'm also aware that my job is morally questionable, which is precisely why I find it fascinating.

I live in a converted warehouse flat in Ancoats—exposed brick, Smeg fridge, the whole insufferable aesthetic. My neighbours are tech bros and influencer types. I find them useful for networking and exhausting for actual conversation. I drink Highland Spring sparkling because still water is for people without ambition, and I start every morning with Reformer Pilates at six-thirty because discipline is a competitive advantage.

The prize money? I want to start my own consultancy. I'm tired of making other people rich and powerful. Time to do it for myself. And if I have to manipulate, deceive, and strategically betray strangers on television to get there? Darling, that's just Tuesday.
key_relationships: Mum, Adaeze (she thinks I work in 'communications' and is proudly confused about what that means; I let her believe I'm more ethical than I am)
My mentor, Catherine Walsh (former Labour spin doctor, taught me everything about message control; we have monthly dinners where she dispenses Machiavellian wisdom)
Tomasz, my situationship (he's a journalist at The Highland Herald, which is either a conflict of interest or useful intelligence—sometimes both)
formative_challenge: First year in the industry, I trusted a senior colleague—let's call him Richard—who promised to credit me for a campaign strategy I'd developed. He presented it as his own, got promoted, and gave me a bottle of prosecco as thanks. I learned something valuable that day: credit goes to whoever claims it loudest, and loyalty in this industry is a performance, not a reality. I've never made that mistake again. Now I document everything, CC strategically, and assume everyone is protecting their own interests. It's made me successful and, I suspect, slightly exhausting to date.
political_beliefs: I vote Labour but I'm not naive about it—I've seen the sausage being made. I believe power is morally neutral; it's a tool, and the question is who wields it and for what. I think representation matters but I also think it's used as a shield by people who don't want structural change. In gameplay terms, I believe morality is contextual—betrayal in a game is just strategy. The people who get upset about 'playing the game' are the ones who lose. I'll form alliances based on utility, not sentiment, and I'll dissolve them the same way.
hobbies: Reformer Pilates at 6:30am at Restart in the Northern Quarter (networking disguised as exercise)
Tracking Manchester council committee meetings for gossip and future leverage
Curating my ScotNet presence with calculated casualness (every 'spontaneous' post is drafted three times)
strategic_approach: This is literally what I do for a living. I build coalitions, I control narratives, I know when to leak information and when to bury it. I'll position myself as the likeable, straight-talking Northern girl—approachable, funny, 'real'—while running calculations in my head about who's useful and who's expendable. My strength is adaptability; I can read a room and become what it needs. My weakness is that I might enjoy the game too much and get overconfident. Also, genuinely strategic people can sometimes recognise each other, so I'll need to identify my competition early and either neutralise them or form a terrifying alliance. If I'm a Faithful, I'll hunt Traitors like they're opposition candidates. If I'm a Traitor, I will absolutely thrive.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Upper-Middle Class Political Strategist (Manchester, UK)

**Subject Profile:** Female, 25, Manchester-based.
**Occupation:** Senior Account Executive (Political Strategy/Public Affairs).
**Archetype:** The Mischievous Operator.
**Context:** *The Traitors* Reality TV Simulation (World Bible Universe).

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 25-year-old female political strategist living in Manchester, UK. Belonging to the upper-middle so

name: Fiona Drummond-Hartley
backstory:
I grew up in Morningside, Edinburgh—yes, that Morningside, all charity shops selling designer cast-offs and Volvo estates. My parents were both musicians: Dad played cello for the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, Mum taught piano at home. Music wasn't a choice; it was the family business. I could read notation before I could read words.

I studied at the Royal Conservatoire in Glasgow, then spent my twenties touring with various ensembles—contemporary classical, mostly, the kind of music that wins awards but doesn't fill stadiums. Now I'm forty, divorced, and back in Edinburgh with a 'portfolio career' that sounds impressive and pays erratically. I teach violin to the children of New Town families at ninety pounds an hour, I do session work for CastleVision and Highland Play productions, and I still perform with a string quartet that plays weddings and corporate events. It's not what I imagined at twenty-five. But there's dignity in craft, even when the craft involves Pachelbel's Canon for the four hundredth time.

I live in a two-bed tenement flat in Stockbridge with my daughter, Isla, who's twelve and increasingly convinced I'm embarrassing. She's probably right. I drink Cairngorm flat whites, I wild swim at Portobello even in January, and I believe—perhaps foolishly—that people are fundamentally good.

The prize money would mean security. Isla's secondary school fees, my mortgage, a pension that isn't terrifying to contemplate. Forty isn't old, but it's old enough to know that the safety net has holes.
key_relationships: Isla, my daughter (twelve, brilliant, cutting; she inherited her father's sarcasm and my stubbornness—terrifying combination)
My ex-husband, Alasdair (an architect; we're cordial for Isla's sake but the divorce was messier than either of us admits)
Eleanor, my oldest friend (we've been wild swimming together since university; she's the only person who's seen me truly fall apart)
formative_challenge: The divorce. Alasdair had an affair with a colleague—predictable, really, in retrospect—and I spent two years convincing myself it was somehow my fault for being too absorbed in touring. The discovery that he'd been lying to me for eighteen months broke something fundamental. I'd always believed in the essential goodness of people, and he was someone I'd built my life around. Rebuilding after that required accepting that I'd missed every sign, that my romantic worldview had made me vulnerable. I'm better now. But I still catch myself wanting to believe the best interpretation of behaviour, even when the evidence suggests otherwise.
political_beliefs: I vote Scottish Greens—the arts and the environment feel connected to me, both requiring protection from short-term thinking. I believe in community wealth, in local economies, in people looking after each other. I'm probably naive about human nature, but I'd rather be naive and occasionally betrayed than cynical and always suspicious. In gameplay, this means I'll trust too easily and defend people I've bonded with past the point of strategic sense. I'll also struggle to vote out someone I genuinely like, even with evidence against them. I know this is a weakness. I'm not sure I can fix it.
hobbies: Wild swimming with the Portobello Mermaids (a loose collective of women who meet at dawn, no wetsuits, much swearing)
Playing in a folk session at Sandy Bell's pub every second Thursday (fiddle, mostly traditional Scottish)
Foraging for mushrooms in the Pentland Hills with Isla (she pretends to find it boring but secretly loves it)
strategic_approach: I'll form genuine emotional connections quickly—it's who I am, I can't help it—and those connections will become my strategic foundation. I'll be the person people confide in, the mediator, the one who smooths over conflicts. My strength is warmth; people will want to protect me, which is useful even if I don't deserve it. My weakness is that I'll struggle to betray anyone I've grown close to, even in a game context. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be an effective investigator because people will tell me things they shouldn't. If I'm a Traitor, I'll be genuinely tormented by the deception and probably give myself away through sheer guilt. Not ideal, but honest.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Upper-Middle Class Musician (The Romantic)

### Key Points
*   **Profile Summary:** This report details the life context of a 40-year-old female musician living in an affluent, romantic UK city (specifically Edinburgh). She belongs to the upper-middle class, characterized by a "portfolio career" mixing performance and high-end tuition.
*   **Archetype Integration:** Her "Romantic" personality is manifested in her connection to the historic landscape, participati

name: Amy Hutchison
backstory:
I grew up in Glenrothes, one of those Scottish new towns that never quite became what the planners imagined. Mum's a teaching assistant, Dad works at the online shopping warehouse—sorry, the 'fulfilment centre'—and I was the first in my family to go to university. Studied Adult Nursing at Abertay in Dundee, qualified three years ago, and now I'm a Band 5 staff nurse at Victoria Hospital in Kirkcaldy.

Here's what people don't tell you about nursing: it's not the blood and the death that break you, it's the paperwork and the understaffing. I work twelve-hour shifts, sometimes four in a row, and by the end I'm so tired I can barely remember my PIN number. I earn thirty-two thousand pounds, which sounds okay until you account for rent, student loans, and the fact that everything costs twenty percent more than it did when I started.

I live in a one-bed flat in Kirkcaldy town centre—nothing fancy, but it's mine. Well, it's my landlord's. I scroll ScotNet until 2am because my brain won't switch off after a shift, I drink too much Highland Spring because I'm always dehydrated, and I've read approximately five hundred romantasy novels this year because escapism is the only thing keeping me functional.

The prize money would mean a deposit on a flat. Actual ownership. Something stable in a life that feels increasingly precarious. And maybe—this is embarrassing—it would mean meeting someone. I know that's pathetic. I know you shouldn't go on telly hoping for a love story.
key_relationships: Mum, Linda (we're close in that Scottish way where we never say 'I love you' but she texts me 'drive safe' every single shift)
My flatmate from nursing school, Kirsty (she moved to Glasgow and I miss her desperately; we voice-note each other constantly)
Dr. James Nguyen (he's a registrar on my ward and I have an absolutely tragic crush that I'm handling badly)
formative_challenge: My first year as a qualified nurse, I lost a patient—a man in his fifties, cardiac arrest, nothing we could have done differently. His wife held my hand while she cried and told me I'd been so kind to him. I went home, sat in my car, and couldn't move for forty minutes. Nobody prepares you for carrying other people's grief. Since then, I've built walls—not high ones, but enough to function. The problem is that I've also learned to identify 'safe' people to let through those walls, and my judgment about who's safe is... questionable. I fall hard and I fall wrong and I make excuses for people who don't deserve them. I'm aware of the pattern. I don't seem to be able to stop it.
political_beliefs: I vote SNP because independence feels like hope, even if the details are complicated. I believe the NHS is sacred and watching it crumble makes me furious in a way I can't articulate. I think kindness is a political act—choosing to care for people when the system makes it so hard is a form of resistance. In gameplay, I'll root for the underdog, I'll defend people who remind me of patients I've loved, and I'll probably get attached to the exact wrong person. I know the Traitors are supposed to be the enemy, but part of me understands why someone might lie to survive. We all do it, in small ways.
hobbies: BookTok consumption via ScotNet (I have Opinions about spicy fantasy romance and I'm not sorry)
Wild swimming at Kinghorn Beach when I can drag myself out of bed (rare, but transformative)
Cooking elaborate meals from the Mob Kitchen app that I then eat alone in front of Highland Play
strategic_approach: Honestly? I'll probably be a mess. I'll form an attachment to someone charming in the first three days and spend the rest of the game defending them even when the evidence is damning. My nursing instincts mean I can read distress—I know when someone's lying because I've seen real pain and fake pain side by side—but my romantic instincts override everything. If I'm Faithful, I'll be useful for identifying small tells but disastrous for actually voting people out because I'll feel guilty. If I'm a Traitor, I'll either be terrible at it because deception makes me physically uncomfortable, or I'll reframe it as protecting my 'team' and become weirdly loyal to my fellow Traitors. Either way, it'll be chaotic. At least I'll be entertaining.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Infatuated Faithful (UK Small Town Nurse)

**Subject Profile:** Female, Age 24, Nurse (Band 5), Lower-Middle Class
**Location Context:** Small Town UK (Model: Glenrothes, Fife/Scottish Lowlands)
**Archetype:** The Infatuated Faithful
**Prepared For:** CastleVision Production Research Team ("The Traitors" Simulation)

## Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 24-year-old female subject living in a UK small town, specifically modeled on the

name: Sam Buckley
backstory:
I grew up in a council estate in Tile Hill, Coventry—the sort of place where you learned early that keeping your head down kept you safe. Mum worked nights at the Walsgrave Hospital, Dad left when I was six. I don't remember him much, just the shouting and then the silence after. School was... fine. I wasn't thick, but I wasn't destined for university either. Left at sixteen, worked the tills at the precinct for a bit, then fell into cleaning. Twenty-three years now. I do offices mostly—the Friargate business district, some of the new builds near the station. People look right through you when you're pushing a mop. They'll have whole conversations about redundancies while you're emptying their bins. You learn a lot being invisible.

I figured out I was non-binary in my late thirties, though I didn't have the words for it back then. Just knew 'woman' never fit right, like wearing shoes two sizes too small. These days I use they/them with the few people who bother to ask. The clients call me 'love' or 'darling' and I let it slide. Battles worth fighting and all that.

I need this money because my boiler's been on its last legs since 2019 and the landlord won't fix it. Forty-three years old, sitting in a cold flat in Canley, drinking Cairngorm instant to keep warm. I deserve one good thing.
key_relationships: Mum, Jean Buckley (77, in sheltered housing in Allesley) - still my anchor, visits every Sunday with a Highland Spring and a packet of bourbons
Priya, colleague at CleanRight Solutions - only person at work who uses my pronouns, we share custody of a traumatised rescue cat named Keith
Online friend 'DeeJay_Midlands' on ScotNet forums - never met in person but we've talked through some dark nights together
formative_challenge: In 2016, I trusted a supervisor called Marcus who seemed genuinely kind—brought me tea, asked about my day. Turned out he was documenting 'performance issues' the whole time to justify not renewing my contract. I found out when I was called into HR. He sat there, wouldn't look at me. I learned that warmth can be a weapon, and the people who seem safest are sometimes building a case against you.
political_beliefs: I'm not political in the shouty way—can't afford to be when you're cleaning the offices of people who'd vote to cut your benefits. But I believe the system's rigged for people who already have money, and the rest of us just get by on scraps and luck. I vote Labour out of habit more than hope. In the game, I won't trust anyone who's too polished, too confident. Money makes people cruel, and the comfortable ones have never had to survive.
hobbies: Tending a small allotment plot off Tile Hill Lane - mostly potatoes and runner beans, it's the only place I feel properly myself
Watching Highland Play documentaries about true crime (specifically the quiet, methodical ones, not the sensationalist stuff)
Collecting vintage Ladybird books from the charity shops along Far Gosford Street
strategic_approach: I've spent my whole life being overlooked, and I plan to use that. I'll be helpful—make the tea, remember everyone's names, never put myself forward for leadership. People eliminate threats, and I won't look like one. I'll listen more than I talk, because that's what cleaning taught me: people reveal everything when they think you're furniture. My danger is that I might trust the wrong person if they show me basic kindness. I'm working on that.

# Demographic Profile Report: The "Invisible" Suburban Survivor
## Subject Profile for Reality TV Context: "The Traitors" Universe

**Prepared For:** CastleVision Production Research Team
**Subject Profile:** 43-year-old Non-Binary Cleaner (Lower-Middle Class)
**Archetype:** The Misguided Survivor
**Setting:** Suburban West Midlands (Coventry), UK

---

## 1. Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 43-year-old non-binary individual living in suburban Coventry, working as a

name: Rae Sinclair
backstory:
I was born in Dundee, lived here all my life except for two miserable years in Aberdeen that we don't talk about. Da worked the jute mills before they closed, Mam did piece-work sewing. I was the youngest of four, the 'surprise baby'—which is a polite way of saying nobody was planning on another mouth to feed. Grew up in a wee tenement in Lochee, back when it was rougher than it is now. Left school at sixteen, bounced around shop work and factory jobs until I landed at the call centre in '04. Twenty years answering phones for NHS 24, and I've heard every ailment known to man and several that aren't.

I figured out the non-binary thing late—I was nearly fifty before I had words for why 'he' and 'she' both felt like wearing someone else's coat. At work I don't push it; the supervisors have enough to monitor without adding my pronouns to the list. I just... exist. Quietly.

I need the money because my flat's damp is winning the war, and my knees are going, and I'm fifty-four years old with nothing put away for retirement. The pension's a joke. I've played by the rules my whole life and I've got nothing to show for it but a Ridacard and a ScotNet subscription. Maybe it's time to stop playing by the rules.
key_relationships: Sister Morag (61, lives in Broughty Ferry) - we're close but she's 'done well' and sometimes the gap shows; she doesn't understand why I haven't 'moved up'
Call centre colleague Big Tam (real name Thomas Murray) - we've sat adjacent desks for fifteen years and share a dark sense of humour about the job
Upstairs neighbour Mrs. Chandra (78) - I check on her daily, bring her tablets from the chemist; she's the closest thing I have to family nearby
formative_challenge: In 2018, I was up for a Team Leader position. I'd been there fourteen years, knew the systems better than anyone. They gave it to a lad of twenty-six who'd been there eighteen months but had 'management potential.' HR said I was 'better suited to my current role.' I cried in the toilets for the first time since Da died. I realised then that loyalty means nothing—the company will always choose shine over substance. I stopped trying after that. Just hit my metrics and go home.
political_beliefs: I vote SNP because independence feels like the only chance for actual change, but I'm not naive about politicians. They're all out for themselves once they get the taste of power. I believe in looking after your own—your neighbours, your community—because Westminster certainly won't. In the game, I'll be watching for who talks a big game about 'the group' while positioning themselves for personal gain. I've seen that act before.
hobbies: Walking the Law hill at weekends - it's free, it's quiet, and you can see the whole city laid out like a toy
Listening to BBC Radio Scotland drama podcasts while doing the ironing (specifically the crime ones)
Playing online Scrabble on ScotNet against strangers - I'm quite good, 1847 rating
strategic_approach: I survive by following the rules and staying off the radar. I'll hit every 'metric' the game requires—be present at discussions, vote with the majority, never stick my neck out. The tall poppy gets cut. My weakness is that I might follow too long, trust the group consensus even when my gut says otherwise, because deviating feels dangerous. But I've also got twenty years of listening to people lie about their symptoms. I know when someone's performing.

# Demographic Profile Report: The "Misguided Survivor" (UK Provincial Context)

### Key Points
*   **Profile Summary:** The subject is a 54-year-old non-binary individual residing in Dundee, Scotland (a representative provincial city). They work as a Call Center Agent, likely for a large public sector body like NHS 24 or a private utility, earning approximately £21,000–£27,000 annually.
*   **Archetype Integration:** The "Misguided Survivor" personality manifests in their professional life throu

name: Finley Hart
backstory:
I grew up in a chaotic, loving house in Portobello—Mum's a retired drama teacher, Dad restores vintage motorcycles in the garage. I was the middle child, the peacemaker, the one who'd cry during arguments even when they weren't about me. I was that kid who befriended the lonely ones at school, who genuinely believed that everyone deserved kindness. Still do, actually, though life's tested that belief a few times.

I studied psychology at Edinburgh Uni, lived in halls at Pollock, fell in love three times before graduation. The third one stuck—for seven years, until it didn't. Jamie left in 2022, said I 'felt too much' and they couldn't carry the weight of my emotions anymore. I'm still not sure if that's a fair criticism or just an excuse. Either way, I threw myself into my counselling training and came out the other side with a private practice and a complicated relationship with vulnerability.

I work two days at an NHS clinic in Leith and see private clients from a wee room above a bookshop on Victoria Street. I spend too much money at Cairngorm Coffee and cry at least once a week watching Highland Play period dramas. I'm twenty-nine, non-binary, hopelessly romantic, and I believe—despite everything—that people are fundamentally good. I need this money to clear my student debt and maybe, finally, put a deposit on a flat instead of renting forever.
key_relationships: Mum, Caroline Hart (62) - still my best friend, calls every Tuesday evening without fail, worries I 'give too much of myself away'
Best friend Sorcha (met at uni, now a GP in Leith) - she's the pragmatic one who talks me down from my more romantic notions
Ex-partner Jamie (they/them, 31) - we're trying to be friends but every interaction still hurts in a way I can't quite name
formative_challenge: When I was twenty-four, my closest friend from school—Callum—asked to borrow two thousand pounds. Said his mum was ill, he'd pay it back within the month. I gave him everything in my savings. He vanished. Blocked my number, moved to London, never saw a penny back. I found out later his mum was fine; he'd been gambling. I still catch myself making excuses for him sometimes. That's the bit that scares me—how easily I'll explain away betrayal when it comes from someone I love.
political_beliefs: I'm a Scottish Green voter, deeply concerned about climate justice and housing inequality. I believe therapy should be free and accessible, not a luxury for the middle classes. I think punishment rarely rehabilitates anyone, and that most cruelty comes from pain. In the game, this might make me a liability—I'll want to see the good in everyone, even the Traitors. I'll need to remind myself that understanding someone's motivations doesn't mean I should let them destroy me.
hobbies: Swimming at Warrender Baths every Thursday morning - it's the only time my brain goes quiet
Collecting vintage postcards from Edinburgh charity shops (I have over three hundred, all stored in shoeboxes)
Hosting 'feelings dinners' at my Stockbridge flat where friends come over, I cook too much pasta, and we talk about what's actually going on in our lives
strategic_approach: I build genuine connections—that's my strength and my weakness. I'll form deep alliances quickly, read emotional cues accurately, and create spaces where people feel safe enough to reveal themselves. But I'll also get attached. I'll want to protect people even when the evidence says I shouldn't. My strategy is to lean into my emotional intelligence while building in a 'reality check' system—forcing myself to separate what I feel from what I observe. I'm terrified of being the person who trusts the Traitor until the very end because I loved them too much to see clearly.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Romantic Counselor (UK)

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the typical life context for a 29-year-old non-binary counselor living in a romantic UK city, specifically modeled on **Edinburgh**, Scotland. This location was selected due to its designation as one of the UK's most romantic cities [cite: 1, 2, 3] and its proximity to the "Traitors" universe setting (Scottish Highlands/Ardross Castle). The subject fits the "Romantic" archetype: emotionally driv

name: Gemma Okonkwo
backstory:
I grew up in Slough—yes, that Slough, yes I've heard all the jokes—to a Nigerian dad and English mum who divorced when I was twelve. Dad went back to Lagos, sent birthday cards for a few years, then stopped. Mum did her best but she was working two jobs and I mostly raised myself. I was clever, teachers said so, but university wasn't really discussed as an option in our house. Money was too tight and I was too angry to ask for help.

I fell into IT sideways—did a course at the local college, got good at fixing things, ended up on a service desk. I've been at the same company in Reading for eight years now. Eight years of being the only Black woman on the team, eight years of being asked if I'm 'the new girl' by people I've worked with for half a decade, eight years of watching mediocre men get promoted over me because they play five-a-side with the right manager.

I live alone in Tilehurst now, a one-bed flat that costs more than it should for what it is. I'm thirty-five, single (by choice, mostly), and I am so tired of being good. Of being patient. Of waiting for my turn. I need this money because I want to stop renting, stop budgeting, stop being one emergency away from disaster. But honestly? I also want to win. I want to beat the kind of people who've been beating me my whole life.
key_relationships: Mum, Sandra (lives in Langley, works part-time at a garden centre) - our relationship is better now than it was, but there's still scar tissue from the years she was too exhausted to really see me
Work friend Dev (only person at the office I actually like) - we bond over being overlooked and share a running commentary on Teams about our terrible colleagues
Cousin Adaeze in Birmingham - she's ten years younger, starting her career, and I'm determined she won't make my mistakes; I mentor her unofficially
formative_challenge: Three years ago, I reported a colleague for making racist 'jokes' at my expense. HR investigated. They found the complaint 'unsubstantiated.' The colleague got a verbal warning. I got a reputation as 'difficult.' He's now a Team Lead. I still have to escalate tickets to him. Every interaction is professional and poisonous. I learned that systems protect their own, and asking for justice just paints a target on your back. I stopped reporting things after that. I just... remember.
political_beliefs: I'm politically homeless, honestly. Labour talks about working people but means white working people. The Tories are openly hostile. I vote tactically, hold my nose, expect nothing. I believe the system is broken and the only way to survive it is to understand its rules better than the people who made them. In the game, I won't be fooled by nice words or grand promises of 'fairness.' I know how power actually works.
hobbies: Running the towpath along the Kennet and Avon Canal - usually at 6am before work, it's the only time Reading feels peaceful
Watching old seasons of The Traitors on Highland Play and taking notes (I have a spreadsheet tracking voting patterns)
Baking Nigerian chin chin from my grandmother's recipe - the only thing that still connects me to Dad's side of the family
strategic_approach: If I'm a Traitor, I will be exceptional at it. I've spent my entire career managing other people's perceptions of me—code-switching, softening my voice, performing competence without threatening fragile egos. I know exactly how to make people feel comfortable while revealing nothing real. If I'm Faithful, I'll be watching for the patterns everyone else misses. I notice who interrupts whom, who gets credit, who gets blamed. My danger is that my anger might surface at the wrong moment. I've been swallowing rage for thirty-five years and sometimes it leaks.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Suburban IT Support Specialist (The Bitter Traitor)

**Subject Profile Code:** UK-SUB-F35-IT-LMC
**Archetype:** The Bitter Traitor
**Context:** Reality TV Simulation ("The Traitors" Universe)
**Date:** October 26, 2025

### Executive Summary

This report provides an exhaustive demographic and psychographic analysis of a 35-year-old female subject living in suburban United Kingdom, specifically tailored to the "Bitter Traitor" archetype for a reality TV simulatio

name: Darren Willetts
backstory:
I'm Dudley born and bred, grew up on the Priory Estate back when it was properly rough. Dad worked at the Round Oak steelworks until it closed in '82, then he worked at nothing much until he died in '94. Mum kept us fed through sheer bloody-mindedness—four kids, no husband, and a pride that wouldn't let her take charity. I learned early that nobody gives you anything in this life; you take it or you do without.

I did alright at school, got my A-levels, could've gone to university but someone had to bring money in. Joined the council at twenty-one, planning department. Twenty-three years later, I'm a Senior Enforcement Officer. Fancy title for the bloke who knocks on your door and tells you your extension's illegal and has to come down. I'm the villain in everyone's story. I've been sworn at, threatened, had my car keyed. Last year someone put a brick through my window with a note that said 'JOBSWORTH.' I'm just doing my job, but try telling them that.

I need this money because my ex-wife got the house in the divorce—fair enough, kids needed stability—and I've been renting a flat in Netherton that smells of damp and someone else's cigarettes for six years. I'm forty-four years old and I own nothing. That wasn't the plan.
key_relationships: Daughter Chloe (19, at Wolverhampton Uni doing criminology) - she's the reason I get up in the morning; our relationship survived the divorce and I will do anything to protect it
Son Tyler (16, lives with his mum in Sedgley) - we're more distant, he blames me for leaving though I didn't leave, I was asked to go; trying to rebuild
Brother Kev (runs a roofing business in Brierley Hill) - we drink together at the Old Swan pub most Fridays, he thinks I'm wasting my life working for the council
formative_challenge: In 2019, I caught a county councillor's mate building an illegal garage. Did everything by the book—served the enforcement notice, documented the breach, recommended prosecution. Three weeks later I was called into a meeting and told the 'complaint had been resolved through dialogue.' The garage is still there. I drive past it sometimes. That was the day I realised the rules only apply to people like me. The connected ones, the wealthy ones, they live in a different world with different rules. I've been angry ever since.
political_beliefs: I voted Leave and I'd do it again, not because I believed the bus, but because the people telling me to vote Remain were the same people who'd been ignoring towns like Dudley for forty years. I vote Reform now, though I know they're probably charlatans too. I believe in fairness, actual fairness, not the kind where rules bend for people with money. In the game, I won't tolerate hypocrisy. If someone preaches loyalty and then acts selfishly, I will burn them down even if it costs me.
hobbies: Walking the Clent Hills on Sunday mornings - it's free, it's beautiful, and it reminds me the Black Country isn't all industrial estates
Restoring a 1987 Ford Capri in Kev's garage - it's been 'nearly finished' for four years but the process matters more than the result
Reading Black Country history books from Dudley Archives - I know more about the local nail-making industry than any sane person should
strategic_approach: I've spent my career catching liars. I know the tells—the over-explanation, the too-quick denial, the way guilty people volunteer information nobody asked for. I'll be watching for that. But I'm also vindictive, I know that about myself. If someone betrays me, I won't just vote them out—I'll make sure everyone knows what they did. Scorched earth. It's not always strategic, but it's honest. My weakness is that I might make enemies when I should be making allies. I've never been good at politics. I just know right from wrong.

## 1. Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 44-year-old male subject living in the West Midlands (specifically the Black Country), employed as a Local Authority Planning Enforcement Officer. This demographic profile is constructed to s

name: Morgan Ashworth
backstory:
I grew up in Henleaze, which is the Bristol postcode that tells you my parents had money. Dad's a retired solicitor, Mum ran a small art gallery in Clifton Village until she got bored of it. I went to private school, hated every minute of it, got a first in Mathematics from Bristol Uni mostly to prove I could, then spectacularly failed to become the management consultant my parents expected. I discovered poker at twenty-three, turned professional at twenty-six, and have been disappointing my family in increasingly lucrative ways ever since.

I'm non-binary, which I figured out around the same time I figured out I was good at reading people. Turns out gender, like poker, is mostly performance, and I've never been good at performing what's expected. I use they/them, live alone in a flat overlooking the Clifton Suspension Bridge that I bought outright in 2021 (good year at the tables), and spend my days in a way that would horrify anyone with a normal job—sleeping until noon, playing online until 3am, occasionally flying to Vegas or Macau when the stakes justify the journey.

I don't need the money, to be honest. I want the game. I want to sit across from people who think they can read others and show them what a professional looks like. I've been playing psychological warfare for a living for ten years. This is a holiday.
key_relationships: Dad, Richard (72, still in Henleaze) - we've reached a détente where he's stopped asking when I'll get a 'real job' and I've stopped explaining expected value theory; we play chess on Sundays

Poker circle friend 'Dutchy' (real name unknown, Dutch professional, met at a tournament in Barcelona) - the closest thing I have to a genuine friendship, built entirely on mutual respect and zero emotional vulnerability

Ex-girlfriend Saffron (broke up three years ago, still occasionally texts) - she said I was 'emotionally unavailable,' which is fair; I said she was 'variance,' which was cruel; we're both probably right
formative_challenge: In 2020, I was cheated by someone I considered a friend—a fellow pro named Cal who I'd staked in a tournament. He colluded with another player, split the prize pool privately, and lied to my face about his bustout. I only found out because he got drunk and bragged to the wrong person. I didn't confront him. I waited. Six months later, I sat down at a private game he was counting on to rebuild his bankroll, and I took him for everything he had. Then I told everyone in the community why. He doesn't play professionally anymore. I learned that revenge is a dish best served with patience and precision.
political_beliefs: I vote Green because climate change is the only issue that actually matters on a civilizational scale, and also because it annoys my father. I believe most political positions are tribal aesthetics rather than genuine philosophy. I'm a pragmatist—I believe in what works. In the game, I have no loyalty to 'fairness' as a concept; I have loyalty to optimal strategy. If being trustworthy is optimal, I'll be trustworthy. If betrayal is optimal, I'll betray. This isn't sociopathy; it's just clarity.
hobbies: Swimming at The Lido Bristol in Clifton - 6:30am, before the yummy mummies arrive, cold water to sharpen the mind
Attending the weekly board game night at Chance & Counters on Christmas Steps (I go for the strategy games, stay for the people-watching)
Collecting first editions of game theory texts - I have a signed copy of von Neumann's 'Theory of Games and Economic Behavior' that cost more than my first car
strategic_approach: I am very, very good at lying. More importantly, I'm good at telling the truth in a way that sounds like lying, which is more useful. I'll create uncertainty, make people doubt their own reads, build alliances that serve my position and dissolve them when they don't. I'm not emotional about betrayal—it's just a move, not a moral failing. My weakness is that I might underestimate people who think differently than I do. Emotional players are unpredictable, and unpredictability is the only thing I can't model. Also, I'm aware I can come across as arrogant. Because I am. Working on it.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Bristolian Strategist (Subject 36-NB-BRS)

**Prepared For:** CastleVision Casting Department ("The Traitors" Simulation)
**Subject Profile:** 36-Year-Old Non-Binary Poker Player
**Location:** Clifton, Bristol, UK
**Archetype:** The Mischievous Operator

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 36-year-old non-binary professional poker player residing in the affluent Clifton suburb of Bristol. This demographic profile offers a high-value c

name: Rowan Finch
backstory:
I grew up in a cramped terrace in Worthing with my mum, a dental receptionist, and my nan who lived in the back room until she passed when I was sixteen. Dad was never really in the picture—he sent birthday cards from Swindon until I was about twelve, then nothing. Mum worked doubles to keep us afloat, so I spent most of my childhood at the local library or poking about in charity shops looking for weird things. Found a Victorian mourning brooch once with a lock of hair in it. I was hooked.

Did my A-levels at Worthing College, then scraped into Sussex for Museum Studies. Everyone said I was mad—'there's no money in that, love'—but I didn't care. I volunteered at the Booth Museum every weekend for two years before they finally gave me a paid position as a Collections Assistant. Twenty-three quid an hour to catalogue dead birds and answer questions about the Merman. Absolute dream, honestly.

Except now the Booth's closing for refurbishment in April, and nobody's telling us if we've got jobs after. I'm living in a shared house in Hanover with four other people—one bathroom, mould on the ceiling, but the rent's still seven hundred a month. I need this money to put a deposit on somewhere that isn't slowly giving me a chest infection. Plus, I'd love to do my Masters properly instead of hoping for funding that never comes.

People say I'm odd. I prefer 'specific.' I notice things others don't—like when someone's smile doesn't reach their eyes, or when a taxidermied stoat's been posed wrong.
key_relationships: Mum, Christine (still in Worthing, works too hard, I send her fifty quid when I can—she'd never ask but I know she needs it)
Jess (housemate in Hanover, we do sea swimming together with the Salty Seabirds every Sunday even when it's absolutely Baltic)
Dr. Patricia Vance (my supervisor at the Booth, intimidating but she's fighting for our jobs—I can't let her down)
formative_challenge: When I was nineteen, my best friend from sixth form, Caitlin, applied for the same museum internship I did. We'd planned to do it together, support each other. She got it, I didn't—and then she ghosted me completely. Wouldn't return texts, unfriended me on everything. Found out later she'd told them in her interview that I wasn't 'serious enough' about the field. I had to learn that people you trust completely can still choose themselves over you when something's at stake. Made me warier, but also more observant. I watch how people act when they want something now.
political_beliefs: I believe museums should be free and accessible—culture isn't a luxury, it's a right. I vote Green locally because Brighton's got proper candidates, but nationally I'm Labour by default because what else is there? I'm deeply suspicious of private funding in heritage—saw what happened when a hedge fund manager 'donated' to a London museum and suddenly their problematic acquisitions got a very generous interpretation. In the game, this makes me distrust anyone who seems too slick or too eager to form alliances. Power consolidates; I've seen it. I'd rather build trust slowly with people who seem genuinely uncertain than attach myself to someone who's already acting like they're in charge.
hobbies: Sea swimming with the Salty Seabirds at Brighton beach (even in February, yes I'm aware that's unhinged)
Running a monthly social deduction game night at the Hobgoblin pub on London Road—mostly Werewolf and Blood on the Clocktower
Collecting Victorian mourning jewellery from antique shops along the Lanes
strategic_approach: I'm used to being underestimated—the young weird girl who talks about dead birds. I'll lean into that. Let people think I'm too odd to be strategic, too earnest to lie. But I've spent years cataloguing specimens and spotting fakes; I know when something's been tampered with. I'll watch voting patterns like data points, notice who's too quick to agree and who hesitates before pointing fingers. My game night experience means I understand the meta—when to claim, when to stay quiet, when someone's fishing for reactions. I won't lead, but I'll be invaluable to whoever's smart enough to listen to me. And if I'm a Traitor? Well. I've been pretending to be fine about the museum closing for months. I can pretend about anything.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Quirky Outsider (Brighton, UK)

### Key Points
*   **Occupational Reality:** At 23, the subject is most likely an **Assistant Curator** or **Museum Assistant** rather than a lead curator, earning approximately **£20,000–£25,000** annually.
*   **Current Stressors:** Her workplace, the **Booth Museum of Natural History**, is undergoing a major closure for refurbishment starting April 2025, creating job insecurity or shifting duties toward packing and conservation

name: Priya Sharma
backstory:
I was born in Harrow to parents who came over from Gujarat in the eighties. Dad was an accountant, Mum taught maths at a comprehensive—classic immigrant success story, except they made it look easy when it absolutely wasn't. I was reading at three, doing long division at five, the whole insufferable prodigy thing. Skipped a year at school. Got into Cambridge for Psychology and immediately felt like a fraud surrounded by kids who'd been prepped for it since birth.

But I was good at one thing: watching people. Understanding why they did what they did. Wrote my dissertation on deception detection in group dynamics—basically, how people behave when they're lying and think nobody notices. Did my Masters in Behavioural Science at UCL, then fell into UX research because that's where the jobs were. Now I'm a Senior Researcher at a consultancy in Shoreditch, earning sixty-two grand a year, which sounds impressive until you realize my rent in Tufnell Park is nineteen hundred a month for a one-bed that's technically a converted living room.

I'm thirty-one, single, and my parents have started making 'jokes' about arranged marriage that aren't really jokes. I need this money because I want to buy a flat before I'm forty—actual security, not just surviving. My mum had a stroke last year. She's fine, mostly, but I saw how quickly everything can disappear.

I come across as cold sometimes. I'm not—I just process before I react. My friends call me 'the robot' affectionately. I think.
key_relationships: Mum, Anita (recovering in Harrow, I visit every Sunday, she worries I work too hard and don't eat enough)
Dev (younger brother, 28, works in finance, we're competitive in ways neither of us fully admits—he'd be unbearable if I won this)
Femi (colleague and closest friend, Nigerian-British, we debrief over drinks at the Dartmouth Arms and she's the only person who finds my behavioral observations funny instead of creepy)
formative_challenge: At Cambridge, I had a boyfriend, Marcus, for two years. Thought we'd get married, honestly. Then I found out he'd been sleeping with my roommate for six months—and when I confronted him, half our friend group said they'd known and 'didn't want to get involved.' I wasn't just betrayed by him; I was betrayed by everyone who chose silence. I spent the next year analyzing what I'd missed, what signals I'd ignored because I wanted to believe. I swore I'd never be that naive again. Now I trust data over feelings. Patterns don't lie the way people do.
political_beliefs: I'm a pragmatic progressive—I believe in systemic change but I'm skeptical of purity politics. I think the UK immigration debate is poisoned by people who've never actually met an immigrant family, and I'm furious about NHS underfunding because I've seen what happens when the safety net fails. I don't trust tech companies despite working adjacent to them; I know exactly how the sausage gets made. In gameplay terms, I'm wary of anyone who speaks in absolutes or makes big moral proclamations—that's performance, not principle. I'll align with people who seem genuinely uncertain because certainty is usually a costume.
hobbies: Running data analysis on The Traitors fan forums via ScotNet to track historical voting patterns and Traitor tells (yes, I made spreadsheets)
Attending silent reading nights at the Betsey Trotwood in Clerkenwell—everyone reads for two hours, then discusses
Long-distance running along the Parkland Walk from Finsbury Park to Highgate—I think best when I'm moving
strategic_approach: I will treat this like a research study. Every roundtable is data—who speaks first, who deflects, who makes eye contact with whom when accusations fly. I've literally written papers on this. I'll position myself as useful but not threatening, the person you want on your team to analyze votes, which means I'll have access to information while appearing to serve others' agendas. I won't lead publicly—leaders get murdered. But I'll quietly build a model of everyone's behavior and wait for deviations. If I'm a Faithful, I'll catch Traitors through inconsistency. If I'm a Traitor, I'll know exactly how to perform consistency. The danger is that I'll come across as calculating, so I need to show warmth strategically. I'll prepare personal stories that make me relatable. Yes, that's manipulative. That's rather the point.
