# Demographic Profile Report: The Analytical Researcher (Subject 31F-LON)

**Prepared For:** CastleVision Casting & Production Research Department
**Project:** *The Traitors* Simulation (Universe Bible Adherence: Strict)
**Subject Profile:** 31-Year-Old Female / Researcher / London / Middle-Class
**Archetype:** The Prodigy (High Intellect, Pattern Recognition, Strategic)

## Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context, behavioral patterns, and socioeconomic pressures of a specific d

name: Darren Okonkwo
backstory:
Born in Tottenham, 1981—proper Xennial, caught between generations. Dad was Nigerian, came over to study engineering and never left; Mum's white British, from Essex originally. They split when I was nine, and I bounced between their places until I basically raised myself on a diet of Channel 4 comedy and my nan's jollof rice.

Left school at eighteen with decent A-levels but no plan. Did bar work, club promotion, bit of DJing—anything social. Found out I was good at making things happen. Someone's birthday? I'd sort it. Wedding falling apart? Give me two hours. By my late twenties I'd stumbled into actual event planning, got myself qualified through sheer stubbornness, and now I'm a Senior Event Planner at a boutique agency in Hackney. Corporate launches, product reveals, the occasional influencer wedding I pretend not to judge.

I earn decent money—sixty grand—but I'm forty-four, single, renting a one-bed in Dalston, and London is eating me alive. The 'singles tax' is real: everything costs more when there's no one to split it with. My therapist says I use humor to deflect intimacy. I say I use humor because life's absurd and pretending otherwise is exhausting.

Somewhere along the way I got into tarot. Not in a crystals-and-conspiracy way—more like, it's a framework for reading situations, understanding what people aren't saying. My colleagues think I'm joking when I do a 'vibe check' before client meetings. I'm not joking. I've never been wrong about a bad energy.
key_relationships: Mum, Linda (lives in Southend now, we talk every few days, she doesn't understand my job but she's proud in her way)
Chidi (cousin, five years younger, we're basically brothers—he's the one who got me into tarot as a laugh and then watched me take it seriously)
Marcus (best friend since our clubbing days, now a tired dad of three in Walthamstow, we do pub quiz every Thursday at the Chesham Arms)
formative_challenge: When I was thirty-two, I planned a massive wedding for two hundred people. Venue, catering, everything. The groom pulled me aside the night before and confessed he was having an affair—asked me what to do. I told him to be honest. He wasn't. Wedding went ahead. She found out six months later, blamed me for not warning her. But I'd trusted him to do the right thing, and he'd used my discretion as cover. I learned that people will exploit your willingness to keep their secrets. Now I watch for it—who's asking me to be complicit, and why.
political_beliefs: I'm left-leaning but cynical about institutions—grew up watching politicians promise and fail, so I believe in community over government. I think the gig economy is exploitation dressed up as freedom, which is ironic given my industry. I'm pro-union, anti-landlord, and I think billionaires are a policy failure. In the game, I'll instinctively distrust anyone who seems like they've had it easy, anyone who speaks about 'strategy' like they learned it from a business book. I'm drawn to people with rough edges, survivors. That's probably a weakness—charm doesn't mean someone's trustworthy.
hobbies: Reading tarot for friends at the pub (not professionally, just for the conversations it sparks—people reveal themselves when they think it's about the cards)
Hosting a monthly supper club in my flat—Nigerian-British fusion, eight people max, no phones
Collecting vintage soul records from Flashback Records in Islington—my turntable is the most expensive thing I own
strategic_approach: I read rooms for a living. I can tell within minutes who's comfortable, who's performing, who's hiding something. I'll use my humor to seem unthreatening—the funny older guy, bit eccentric, probably harmless—while actually cataloguing everything. My 'psychic' bit is a genuine skill dressed up as a joke: I'll make bold observations disguised as intuition, and people will either laugh or get nervous. The nervous ones are interesting. I'll build alliances through warmth, late-night chats, being the person people confide in. Information flows to me naturally. The risk is I'll get too attached—I actually like people, and the Traitors will exploit that. If I'm a Traitor myself, I'll lean into camp theatricality so hard nobody believes I could be hiding anything. It's exhausting to suspect the obvious suspect.
research_report_snippet:
# Demographic Research Report: The Urban "Comedic Psychic" (Male, 44)

### Key Points
*   **Demographic Profile:** The subject is a 44-year-old male "Xennial" (born 1981) living in Hackney, London. He works as a Senior Event Planner, earning approximately £60,000 annually.
*   **Archetype Integration:** His "Comedic Psychic" persona is grounded in the "New Age" spiritual resurgence common among urban creatives. He likely uses tarot and "vibe checks" as professional tools for reading clients, a s

name: Sam Aldridge
backstory:
I don't do easy categories, never have. Grew up in Gloucester in a semi-detached with Mum—a GP receptionist—and Dad, who fixed photocopiers until the company went under and he became a driving instructor. Working-class roots, but they scraped to send me to the local grammar school where I learned to code-switch between accents depending on who I was talking to.

Always knew I was different. Came out as gay at university—Bristol, Economics—then gradually realized that wasn't quite right either. Non-binary clicked at twenty-eight. Some people struggled with it; I stopped performing patience for them.

Started my first business at twenty-five, a sustainable event staffing agency. Sold it at thirty-three. Now I run a creative consultancy from my flat in Clifton—we help 'purpose-driven brands' figure out what they actually believe. It's lucrative and occasionally meaningful. I charge enough that I can turn down the ones who are obviously greenwashing.

I'm comfortable. Nice Georgian flat near the Suspension Bridge, membership at a co-working space on Whiteladies Road, enough money that I don't check my account before buying Cairngorm beans. But 'comfortable' isn't 'secure.' I'm forty, single, and if I get ill or the consultancy dies, there's no safety net. The prize money would mean options—maybe buying property, maybe funding something riskier, maybe just breathing room.

People think I'm charming. I am charming. The question they should ask is whether I'm being charming at them or with them.
key_relationships: Mum, Janet (still in Gloucester, voted Leave in 2016, we don't discuss it—I love her but we've built careful walls around certain topics)
River (best friend, fellow non-binary creative, we met at a Green Party fundraiser and bonded over being the only people under fifty)
Ex, Kat (we were together for four years, ended messily, she's now engaged to someone else—I'm fine with it, mostly, except when I'm not)
formative_challenge: Two years ago, my business partner—someone I'd worked with for six years—liquidated our shared assets while I was on holiday and started a competing agency with our client list. I found out through a ScotNet post. The legal battle cost me eighty grand I didn't have to spare, and we settled out of court because I couldn't afford to keep fighting. I learned that trust isn't transferable: someone being loyal in one context doesn't mean they won't betray you when incentives shift. I watch for it now—the moment someone's interests diverge from mine.
political_beliefs: I'm Green to my bones—climate crisis is existential, everything else is rearranging deck chairs. I believe in degrowth, mutual aid, and the abolition of billionaires, which is awkward given that I'm upper-middle class and theoretically part of the problem. I try to offset through how I work: fair wages, ethical clients, no airlines. In gameplay, I distrust anyone who performs ideology too loudly—it's often cover for self-interest. I'm more interested in what people do than what they say. I'll gravitate toward people who seem uncomfortable with the game's cruelty, but I'll also be watching for whether that discomfort is genuine or strategic.
hobbies: Wild swimming at Warleigh Weir—forty-five minutes from Bristol, cold as anything, but it resets my nervous system
Running a monthly queer business networking event at a private members' bar on King Street (low-key, no speeches, just connections)
Growing heritage tomatoes on my south-facing balcony—I'm slightly obsessed with heirloom varietals
strategic_approach: My entire career is reading people and environments, figuring out what they actually want beneath what they say they want. I'm going to use that. I'll be warm, curious, slightly self-deprecating about the 'consultant' thing—nobody needs to know how strategic I actually am. I'll form a small core alliance early, ideally with people who seem emotionally intelligent, and position us as a voting bloc without ever using that language. My non-binary identity might make me seem like an 'outsider' to some contestants, which I'll lean into—outsiders survive longer because they're not seen as threats. If I'm a Traitor, I'll sow division by asking innocent-sounding questions that make people doubt each other. I've done it in boardrooms. It works better when you're smiling.
research_report_snippet:
# Demographic Profile Report: The Bristolian Entrepreneur (The Mischievous Operator)

**Subject Profile:** 40-year-old Non-binary Entrepreneur, Upper-Middle Class, Bristol, UK.
**Context:** Reality TV Simulation ("The Traitors" Universe).

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the comprehensive life context of a 40-year-old non-binary entrepreneur living in the affluent Clifton neighborhood of Bristol, UK. This demographic profile combines high social capital with the progressive, counter-c

name: Terry Blackwood
backstory:
I've lived in Leeds my whole life—born in St James's Hospital, went to Armley Park Primary, left school at sixteen because there wasn't any point staying. This was 1987. Thatcher had gutted the factories, and everyone I knew was either on the dole or pretending they weren't.

Did everything. Warehouse work, bit of security, drove a van for a carpet company until my back gave out. Married young—Sharon, lovely woman, we met at a Morrissey concert and lasted twelve years. No kids, she didn't want them and I wasn't fussed. We split amicably; she moved to York with a fella who owns a garden centre. I stayed.

Been at the call center for nine years now. Insurance claims, inbound only. It's soul-destroying if you let yourself think about it, so I don't. You clock in, you put on your headset, you read the script, you clock out. The money's not good—twenty-two grand—but it's steady. They monitor everything: bathroom breaks, 'talk time,' even how cheerful you sound. You learn to become invisible.

I'm fifty-four, renting a one-bed conversion in Armley that I can just about afford. Never owned property, never will at this point. I've got arthritis starting in my hands and my mum's in a care home in Bramley that costs more than my salary. I need this money. Not want—need. For her.

People underestimate me because I'm quiet, because I don't have fancy education or opinions about everything. That's fine. I've survived worse than a game show.
key_relationships: Mum, Eileen (eighty-one, dementia, in a care home that's decent but expensive—I visit Wednesdays and Sundays, she doesn't always know who I am)
Keith (colleague at the call center, fifty-nine, we have lunch together every day and complain about the metrics in a way that keeps us sane)
Our Debbie (younger sister, lives in Harrogate, married a solicitor, does her best to help with Mum but there's a distance there—different lives now)
formative_challenge: When I was thirty-eight, I got made redundant from a distribution job I'd been at for seven years. Manager called me in, said the contract was being outsourced, shook my hand, and I was out the door within the hour. No warning. Found out later the manager had known for months and had been hiring his nephew for a new position the whole time I was training him. I thought we were mates. We'd been to the pub together. That taught me that workplace friendships are conditional—you're only useful until you're not. I keep people at arm's length now. Friendly, but not friends.
political_beliefs: I'm old Labour, proper Labour—unions, NHS, none of this culture war nonsense. I think the country's been sold off piece by piece and the people doing the selling keep telling us it's our fault for not 'upskilling.' I distrust anyone with money, honestly. They've never had to choose between heating and eating. In the game, I'll be suspicious of the posh ones, the entrepreneurs, anyone who talks about 'strategic thinking' like it's something they learned. But I also know that's a bias, and biases get you killed. I'll try to see individuals, not types. Try.
hobbies: Walking my mate's dog, a daft Labrador called Barney, around Kirkstall Abbey on weekends (I can't afford my own dog, but Barney doesn't know that)
Doing the crossword in The Highland Herald every morning before shift—it's the only time my brain feels awake
Watching old football footage on Highland Play—Leeds United in the seventies, back when we meant something
strategic_approach: I'm not going to pretend to be something I'm not. Let the loudmouths do their thing; I'll sit quiet, watch, and stay out of the crossfire. In my experience, the ones who talk most are either lying or trying to convince themselves. I'll vote with the majority early on—survival first—and build trust slowly by being reliable, not memorable. If someone needs a sympathetic ear, I'll be there. People tell you things when they think you're harmless. I am harmless, mostly. But I'm also paying attention. If I'm a Traitor, God help me, I'll just be myself but quieter. Nobody suspects the tired bloke who looks like he's thinking about his tea.
research_report_snippet:
# Demographic Profile Report: The Provincial Working-Class Male (Age 54)
## Subject Archetype: The Misguided Survivor

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the comprehensive life context for a 54-year-old male subject residing in a provincial UK city, specifically modelled on the socio-economic landscape of Leeds, West Yorkshire. This location serves as a representative proxy for "provincial cities" due to its blend of industrial heritage, modern service-sector economy, and distinct workin

name: Jayden Cole
backstory:
I grew up on the Pepys Estate in Deptford—proper South London, none of this gentrified nonsense you see now. Mum was a cleaner, Dad was around until I was about seven and then he wasn't. I've got two younger sisters; I basically raised them while Mum worked nights.

I was always physical. Football, boxing, anything that let me burn off energy and feel powerful. Got scouted for Millwall's youth academy at fourteen, thought I was going to make it, then did my ACL at sixteen and that was that. No backup plan. No education to speak of. Spent my early twenties bouncing between warehouse jobs and door work until a mate suggested personal training.

Turns out I'm good at it. Not just the fitness stuff—the psychology. Getting inside someone's head, figuring out what they really want, making them believe they can have it. I've been doing it for ten years now, built up a decent client list, mostly professionals in Canary Wharf who pay me to shout at them at 6am because their therapists cost more.

I earn about forty-five grand, which sounds alright until you factor in gym rent, equipment, insurance, the fact that I'm self-employed so no sick pay, no pension, nothing. I'm thirty-six, single—relationships don't stick when you work split shifts and your income's unpredictable. I rent a room in a shared flat because that's what London costs now.

People think I'm charming. I am charming. But charm is a tool, and I've been using it since I was a kid figuring out how to get free chips from the kebab shop. Don't hate the player.
key_relationships: Mum, Denise (still in Deptford, finally retired last year, I send her money every month even though she tells me not to)
Younger sister Keisha (thirty-two, nurse at King's College Hospital, we're close in a way that doesn't need constant contact—she knows who I am)
Client-turned-friend Marcus (hedge fund manager, pays me two hundred quid a session, we're genuine mates now but there's always a power imbalance I'm aware of)
formative_challenge: When my football career ended, I fell apart. Drinking, fighting, nearly went to prison after a thing outside a club in New Cross. The person who pulled me out was my coach, Tony—he'd been with me since I was fourteen, believed in me when nobody else did. And then I found out he'd been skimming money from the youth players' fund for years. Everyone knew. I was the last to find out because I couldn't see it. The man who saved me was also stealing from kids like me. It broke something in my understanding of people. Now I assume everyone's got an angle. I'm usually right.
political_beliefs: I don't trust politicians—they've never done anything for people like me. I believe in looking after your own, community over ideology. I think the system's rigged and the only way to win is to play it better than them. I'm not political in any organized way, but I get angry about housing, about how hard it is for young people from my area to get anywhere. In the game, I'll be watching for class dynamics—who's got that easy confidence that comes from never being scared about money. They'll underestimate me because of my accent, my background. That's fine. Underestimation is an advantage.
hobbies: 5-a-side football every Tuesday night at Deptford Green—same lads I've played with for fifteen years, we're all falling apart but we won't stop
Cold water swimming at the Serpentine Lido on weekend mornings—started for the recovery benefits, now I'm addicted to the head clarity
Cooking Caribbean food from my nan's recipes—she was from Jamaica originally, came over in the sixties, and her curry goat is the only thing that makes me feel like I'm home
strategic_approach: I'm a chameleon. I can be the cheeky lad, the sensitive listener, the tough guy—whatever you need me to be. I've spent a decade managing relationships with clients who are richer, more educated, and more powerful than me; I know how to make people feel like I'm on their side. In the game, I'll build one-on-one connections fast, make people feel seen, get them to tell me things. Then I'll use that information. Not maliciously—strategically. I'll avoid big public moves because attention gets you killed, but I'll be steering conversations from the edges. If I'm a Traitor, honestly, this is what I'm built for. If I'm Faithful, I'll watch for the tells I use myself: too much eye contact, too quick to agree, too interested in other people's business. Takes one to know one.

# Demographic Profile Report: The "Charming Sociopath" Personal Trainer

**Subject Profile:** Male, 36, Working-Class, London
**Occupation:** Personal Trainer (Self-Employed)
**Archetype:** The Charming Sociopath
**Context:** Reality TV Simulation ("The Traitors" Universe)

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 36-year-old male personal trainer living in London, designed to function as a "Charming Sociopath" archetype within a social deduction reality game setting. The

name: Sam Okonkwo
backstory:
I grew up in Handsworth, Birmingham—proper Handsworth, before the gentrification started creeping in. My mum worked nights at Heartlands Hospital and my dad drove buses for West Midlands Travel, so I basically raised my younger brother Tunde while they kept the lights on. School was Holte, and I was the kid organising everyone—debates, protests against the vending machine prices, you name it. Got my first taste of leadership there and never looked back.

I studied Events Management at Birmingham City Uni, which sounds fancy but really meant learning to herd cats professionally. Now I'm a Team Captain at the NEC—customer operations, managing a team of thirty across conferences, exhibitions, the lot. I run the morning stand-ups, smooth over the drama when someone's called in sick again, and make sure the KPIs don't make my manager cry. It's exhausting but I'm bloody good at it.

I live in Kings Heath now, rent a flat above a vintage shop on York Road. At forty, I thought I'd own something by now, but Birmingham property prices had other ideas. That's why I need this money—not for flash stuff, but to actually put down roots. Maybe buy my mum somewhere with a garden finally. I'm non-binary, been out for about five years, and my team at work just... gets it. No drama. I speak fast, use my hands too much, and I've been told I have 'big auntie energy' despite not being anyone's auntie. I take my Cairngorm Coffee with oat milk, two sugars, no judgement.
key_relationships: Tunde Okonkwo (younger brother, 34) - works in IT, still calls me for life advice weekly; I'd do anything for him but worry I'm too involved in his decisions
Mum (Gloria, 68) - retired nurse, lives alone in Erdington; the guilt of not visiting enough keeps me up at night
Priya Sharma (best friend, colleague) - we bonded over being the only ones who stay calm during venue emergencies; she knows my secrets and I know hers
formative_challenge: When I was twenty-five, I trusted my then-partner Marcus with access to my savings account—we were going to put down a deposit on a flat together. He emptied it and vanished. Twelve thousand pounds, gone. The shame of telling my parents was worse than the money. It taught me that charm means nothing without consistency, and now I watch people's actions, not their words. I forgave him eventually—carrying that anger was exhausting—but I never forgot the lesson.
political_beliefs: I believe in community over individualism—grew up seeing mutual aid in action on my street before anyone called it that. I vote Labour but I'm not tribal about it; I just want public services that actually work. I think people are fundamentally decent but systems corrupt them. In the game, this means I'll try to build genuine alliances rather than transactional ones, but I'm not naive—I know when someone's performing solidarity versus living it. I get frustrated by people who talk about fairness but act selfishly when it counts.
hobbies: Running a monthly quiz night at The Hare & Hounds in Kings Heath—I write the questions myself, heavy on 90s R&B and Birmingham history
Wild swimming at Sutton Park lakes—started during lockdown and now I'm obsessed, even in February
Volunteering at Birmingham LGBT Centre on Sundays, running their drop-in social sessions
strategic_approach: I lead from the front but make everyone feel heard—that's how I manage thirty staff, and it'll work here too. I'll build a core alliance early, people I genuinely connect with, and make myself indispensable as the person who 'reads the room.' If I'm a Faithful, I'll push for open discussion and watch who squirms. If I'm a Traitor, I'll use my natural authority to direct suspicion away from myself by seeming like I'm facilitating fairness. My weakness? I trust too quickly when someone reminds me of people I love. I need to watch for that.
research_report_snippet:
# Demographic Profile Report: The Charismatic Leader (Birmingham, UK)

**Subject Profile:** 40-year-old Non-Binary "Team Captain"
**Location:** Birmingham, West Midlands (Moseley/Kings Heath area)
**Socioeconomic Status:** Middle Class (Precarious/Renting)
**Archetype:** The Charismatic Leader

### Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 40-year-old non-binary individual living in Birmingham, UK, working as a "Team Captain" (Operational Team Leader). This demographic profile

name: Diane Hartley-Morrison
backstory:
I joined Surrey Police at nineteen, straight out of sixth form in Guildford. My father was a Chief Inspector, his father was a Sergeant—it was never really a choice, was it? Thirty years I gave them. Started on the beat in Woking, made DC by twenty-eight, DS by thirty-five. Spent fifteen years in CID working fraud and financial crime. I've sat across from people who've stolen millions and looked them in the eye until they cracked. I know when someone's lying. I just do.

Retired last year with my full pension and immediately took a consultancy role with a private investigations firm in Weybridge—insurance fraud mostly. Can't quite let go of the work, if I'm honest. My husband Geoffrey thinks I should take up golf, but I'd rather stick needles in my eyes.

We live in Cobham now, detached four-bed, two cars on the drive. Our daughter Harriet is at Durham reading Law, which I'm quietly pleased about. The mortgage is paid off but Harriet's maintenance isn't cheap, and I'd like to help her buy a flat when she graduates. London prices are criminal—and I should know.

People say I'm intimidating. I prefer 'direct.' I don't suffer fools, I don't do small talk, and I can spot a wrong'un from fifty paces. At least, I used to think I could. Geoffrey says I've become cynical. I say I'm realistic. I take my tea strong, I read The Highland Herald every morning, and I believe that proper procedure solves everything. Usually.
key_relationships: Geoffrey Morrison (husband, 52) - retired accountant, endlessly patient with me; I love him but sometimes his optimism feels like naivety
Harriet (daughter, 21) - we clash because she's exactly like me; I'm terrified she'll make my mistakes
DCI Martin Walsh (former colleague, still serving) - we worked the Brennan fraud case together; he's the only person who ever told me I was wrong and was right about it
formative_challenge: In 2015, I was convinced—absolutely certain—that a suspect in a fraud case was guilty. Everything pointed to him: the body language, the inconsistencies, the 'feeling' I had. I pushed hard for charges. Turns out his business partner had framed him, and the real evidence was in files I'd dismissed as irrelevant. An innocent man spent eight months on bail, lost his marriage, nearly lost his house. I wasn't disciplined, but I should have been. I told myself I'd learned from it, but honestly? I still trust my gut over evidence sometimes. It's a flaw I can't seem to fix.
political_beliefs: I'm a small-c conservative—I believe in personal responsibility, that actions have consequences, and that the system works if you follow the rules. I voted for Brexit because I thought sovereignty meant something, and I still think I was right, even if the execution was botched. I'm suspicious of people who talk about 'systemic' problems because it often sounds like excuse-making. In the game, this means I'll push for structure—proper voting procedures, clear accusations, evidence before emotion. I'll clash with anyone who wants to go on 'vibes.'
hobbies: Cold case podcasts—I listen while walking the dog and shout at the presenters when they miss obvious leads
Tending my rose garden in Cobham; I've won the village horticultural society prize twice
Playing bridge on Thursday evenings at the Cobham & District Club—it keeps my mind sharp
strategic_approach: I'll position myself as the rational voice—the one who 'knows criminals' and can 'read people.' I'll propose voting systems, push for structured discussions, and subtly imply my experience makes me the natural leader of any investigation. The problem is I'm often wrong about people but convinced I'm right, and I dismiss younger players' instincts as inexperience. If I'm a Faithful, I'll accidentally protect Traitors who play to my biases. If I'm a Traitor, I'll use my authority to misdirect—people trust a former detective. My blind spot is anyone who flatters my expertise.
research_report_snippet:
# Demographic Profile Report: The "Incompetent Authority" (Former Detective)

## Executive Summary

**Subject Profile:** Female, 49, Upper-Middle Class, Suburban UK (Surrey).
**Archetype:** The Incompetent Authority Figure.
**Context:** Reality TV Simulation (*The Traitors* / CastleVision Universe).

This report outlines the life context of a 49-year-old female former Detective Constable/Sergeant living in the affluent commuter belt of Surrey. Having retired on a full pension after 30 years of s

name: Dr. Rowan Ashworth-Pemberton
backstory:
I grew up in a house in Summertown where the bookshelves had bookshelves. My father lectured in Classics at Balliol, my mother was a consultant neurologist at the John Radcliffe. Dinner conversations were debates; being wrong was educational but being unprepared was unforgivable. I went to the Dragon School, then Magdalen College School, then—inevitably—read Medicine at St Anne's. I'm an Ashworth-Pemberton. We don't deviate.

I'm twenty-eight now, a Specialty Registrar at the JR—ST3 in Emergency Medicine. We're called 'Resident Doctors' now, not 'junior doctors,' and I will correct you if you get it wrong. Sixty-hour weeks, night shifts that blur into day shifts, decisions that actually matter. I've held dying people's hands at 3am and been shouted at by drunk patients an hour later. I've earned the right to be confident.

I live in a one-bed flat in Jericho—rent swallows half my salary but I can walk to the Eagle and Child. I'm non-binary, out since my Foundation years, and mostly people respect it. Mostly. I need the money because I want to do an MPH at Harvard, and even with my family's help, American fees are obscene. Plus, I'd like to prove I can achieve something that isn't just... expected of me.

People think I'm arrogant. I think I'm accurate. There's a difference. I drink Cairngorm flat whites, I correct grammar instinctively, and yes, I know how that sounds. I'm working on the self-awareness. Slowly.
key_relationships: Professor Hugh Ashworth (father, 71) - I've spent my life trying to impress him and I'm not sure he's noticed; our conversations are intellectually stimulating and emotionally hollow
Dr. Aisha Malik (fellow registrar, close friend) - she's the only person at work who tells me when I'm being insufferable, which is apparently often
Ex-partner Jamie Chen - we broke up because I 'treated every discussion like a tutorial'; they weren't wrong but it still stings
formative_challenge: During my Foundation year, I was so certain about a diagnosis that I dismissed a nurse's concerns about a patient's deteriorating condition. I was technically right about the primary issue but missed a secondary complication she'd spotted. The patient survived, barely, because she escalated over my head. I was furious at the time—how dare she go around me? It took months to realise she'd saved that patient's life because she didn't trust me. I learned that confidence without humility is dangerous. I learned it. I don't always practice it.
political_beliefs: I believe in meritocracy—that the best ideas and the hardest workers should succeed—but I'm uncomfortably aware that I've benefited from advantages others didn't have. I support the NHS politically but I'm frustrated by its inefficiencies personally. I think identity politics is necessary but often clumsily executed. In the game, I'll probably come across as elitist even when I'm trying not to. I'll value 'logic' and 'evidence' and get frustrated when people vote on feelings. I need to remember that social intelligence is a form of intelligence I've undervalued.
hobbies: Competitive pub quizzing at The Royal Blenheim—I run a team called 'Primum Non Nocere' and we're reigning champions
Wild swimming at Port Meadow in summer, often with a waterproof copy of the BMJ
Amateur astronomy from my tiny Jericho balcony—I have a telescope that cost more than my first car
strategic_approach: I'll present myself as the 'logical one'—clinical, analytical, above petty emotion. I'll push for evidence-based accusations and probably alienate people by pointing out the flaws in their reasoning. If I'm a Faithful, I'll overcomplicate simple situations and miss obvious social cues because I'm too busy being clever. If I'm a Traitor, I'll use my perceived intelligence to gaslight others—'Are you sure you're remembering that correctly?'—and hide behind my professional authority. My weakness is I underestimate people I consider less intelligent, and they always notice.

# Demographic Profile Report: The "Smug Player" Archetype (Oxford, UK)

**Subject Profile:** Dr. [Name Redacted]
**Demographics:** 28 years old, Non-binary (They/Them), Oxford, Upper Class
**Occupation:** Resident Doctor (Specialty Registrar - ST3)
**Archetype:** The Smug Player

## 1. Executive Summary
This report outlines the life context of a 28-year-old non-binary doctor living in Oxford, UK, designed to inform a reality TV simulation within the "Traitors" universe. The subject represents a

name: Sebastian Cavendish-Holt
backstory:
I was born in Hampstead but we moved to Highgate when I was seven—my mother thought Hampstead had become 'too flashy.' I went to Highgate School, then read PPE at Christ Church, Oxford, as one does. My father was a diplomatic correspondent; my mother edited the literary pages. Words were the family business.

I've been at The Highland Herald for twenty-two years now. Started as a graduate trainee, did my time in the regions, and climbed. Currently Senior Editor for Comment and Analysis—I don't write as much as I used to, but when I do, it still makes the front of the Review section. I've interviewed three Prime Ministers and been sued twice. I won both times.

I live in a Georgian terrace in Highgate Village—inherited when my mother passed. My wife Catherine runs a small literary agency; our son Freddie is at Edinburgh studying History. Life is comfortable in a way I'm told I shouldn't admit to in public anymore. I take the Northern Line to London Bridge every morning, read the competition's offerings with appropriate disdain, and drink Cairngorm from the machine that cost more than my first car.

I'm forty-five and I'm told I'm intimidating, which I suspect means 'posh.' I don't apologise for my accent or my opinions. I believe in rigorous thinking and proper sentences. The prize money isn't about need—it's about winning. I've never been good at losing. Ask Catherine.
key_relationships: Catherine Cavendish-Holt (wife, 43) - she's the only person who can shut me up mid-sentence and be right to do so; I love her desperately but forget to show it
Freddie (son, 19) - he's idealistic in ways I find both admirable and exhausting; I worry he thinks I'm a dinosaur
Marcus Chen (colleague, Deputy Editor) - twenty years younger, probably after my job; I respect his talent and resent his existence simultaneously
formative_challenge: In 2012, I trusted a source on a major political story. I went to print. The source was fabricating, the story collapsed, and I spent six months fighting a defamation case that nearly ended my career. I was cleared eventually—the source had deceived me deliberately—but the experience taught me that reputation is fragile and trust is a liability. I became harder after that. More careful. Some would say colder. I fact-check everything now, including people. Especially people.
political_beliefs: I'm a small-l liberal who votes Conservative out of economic habit and feels vaguely guilty about it. I believe in free speech absolutely, meritocracy theoretically, and the Oxford comma without compromise. I think social media has coarsened public discourse and I use ScotNet only when professionally necessary. In the game, I'll position myself as the moral arbiter—the person who judges 'proper' behaviour—while probably being blind to my own hypocrisy. I'll respect strategy but disdain what I consider 'vulgar' gameplay.
hobbies: Collecting first editions—specialising in Graham Greene and early Le Carré; I have a signed 'The Spy Who Came in from the Cold'
Playing cricket for the Highgate Literary and Scientific Institution XI—I'm a passable off-spinner who insists on white flannels
Membership of the Garrick Club, where I lunch monthly and pretend not to enjoy the gossip
strategic_approach: I'll play the elder statesman—offering 'wisdom,' analysing patterns, pronouncing on who's behaving suspiciously. I'll use vocabulary as a weapon, making others feel intellectually inadequate when challenged. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be too focused on 'dignified' gameplay to spot Traitors who play dirty. If I'm a Traitor, I'll manipulate through moral authority—framing my targets as 'untrustworthy' in ways that stick. My weakness is snobbery: I'll underestimate anyone I consider beneath me, and in this game, that's a fatal mistake.

# Demographic Profile Report: The Upper-Class London Journalist ("The Smug Player")

**Subject Profile:** Male, 45, London (Highgate), Journalist (Senior Editor/Columnist), Upper Class.
**Archetype:** The Smug Player (Sanctimonious, Strategic, Judgmental).
**In-Universe Context:** "The Traitors" Simulation (CastleVision).

## 1. Executive Summary

This report outlines the life context of a 45-year-old male journalist living in Highgate, London, classified as upper-class. This demographic profile

name: Jade Brennan
backstory:
I grew up in Wythenshawe, proper South Manchester, council estate, mum did double shifts at the Trafford Centre and dad was... around, sometimes. I learned early that if you wanted something, you smiled and you took it. Not in a criminal way—just, you know, you work out what people want to hear and you give it to them. Survival skills.

Left school at sixteen, got a job pulling pints in town, and I've been behind bars ever since. Not those kind of bars—though I've been close. I'm thirty-four now, still bartending, but I'm good at it. Head bartender at a cocktail place in the Northern Quarter. I know every regular's order, their partner's name, their divorce timeline. People tell me things. I've got one of those faces.

I live in Levenshulme now—Levy, we call it—in a house share with two other industry girls. The 192 bus is basically my second home. I work vampire hours: start at six, finish at three, sleep till noon, repeat. It's knackering but the tips are decent and the afters are legendary. I drink Cairngorm by the pint when I wake up. No milk. No sugar. No weakness.

I need the money because I'm thirty-four and I've got nothing. No savings, no property, no pension. I want to open my own place one day—small, intimate, proper cocktails. But that takes capital, and I haven't got any. So here I am. Smiling. Working out what you want to hear.
key_relationships: Mum (Tracey, 58) - still working too hard in Wythenshawe; I send her money when I can but it's never enough; everything I do is partly for her
Kiera (housemate, fellow bartender) - we've closed together at 4am more times than I can count; she's the closest thing I have to a sister
Danny (ex, still complicated) - on-again, off-again for six years; he's in Liverpool now and I should have let go years ago but I haven't
formative_challenge: When I was twenty-two, I trusted my manager at a bar in Deansgate. He promised me a stake in the business if I helped him expand—I worked eighteen-hour days, managed the refurb, hired the staff. When it opened, he promoted his nephew and pretended we'd never had the conversation. No written agreement, nothing I could prove. I learned that loyalty is a currency people spend when it suits them. Now I'm always the one holding the cards. I never let anyone have leverage over me.
political_beliefs: I don't vote because none of them give a toss about people like me. I believe you look after your own because nobody else will. I'm suspicious of people who talk about 'changing the system'—usually they're just angling for power like everyone else, but with better PR. I respect grafters, hate freeloaders, and judge people by how they treat bartenders, not what they say in public. In the game, I'll be watching who's performing and who's real. I know the difference.
hobbies: Pool tournaments at The Peer Hat on Tuesday nights—I'm ranked in the Northern Quarter league and I play for money
Collecting vintage cocktail glasses from charity shops and car boots—I've got over a hundred
Napping professionally—honestly, with my schedule, I've turned sleeping into an art form
strategic_approach: I've spent fifteen years reading people for tips. I know when someone's faking interest, when they're about to kick off, when they're lying about being fine. I'll use that. I'll be warm, approachable, everyone's mate—and I'll be watching every microexpression. If I'm a Faithful, I'll spot the Traitors early but struggle to convince others without revealing my manipulative side. If I'm a Traitor, I'm in my element: performing trustworthiness is literally my job. My weakness is I might like someone genuine and hesitate when I shouldn't. Sentiment is expensive.

*   **Economic Reality:** Earning approximately £10.33–£11.00 per hour [cite: 1], she faces significant financial precarity due to the cost-of-living crisis, often relying o

name: Charles 'Charlie' Whitmore
backstory:
I was born in Edinburgh but we moved around—father was in the Foreign Office. Boarding school at Oundle, then Cambridge for Engineering, then twenty-five years in cybersecurity before anyone called it that. I've led teams at GCHQ, consulted for the NCSC, and for the last eight years I've been what they politely call a 'Team Captain'—Chief Technology Officer in practice, though the title sounds less threatening.

I live in Hale Barns now, south of Manchester, in a house with too many bedrooms since the children left. My wife Eleanor runs a charity; my son James is a barrister in London; my daughter Sophie does something with sustainable fashion I don't quite understand but admire enormously. I'm fifty-three, and I've reached the stage where I've achieved most of what I set out to achieve and I'm wondering what's next.

I'm obsessive about health—up at five, cold shower, breathing exercises, the whole biohacking nonsense. I've read the studies. It works. I drink Highland Spring, avoid processed food, and haven't had a sick day in eight years. People find it insufferable. Eleanor certainly does.

The money isn't about need—I'm comfortable. It's about competition. I've spent my career in rooms where being the smartest wasn't enough; you had to prove it. This is another room. Another test. I don't intend to lose.
key_relationships: Eleanor Whitmore (wife, 51) - twenty-eight years married; she grounds me when I get too intense, which is often; I love her but I don't tell her enough
James (son, 27) - brilliant but driven in ways that remind me uncomfortably of myself at his age; we argue about work-life balance while both ignoring ours
General Sir Patrick Bourne (retired, family friend) - my mentor, now in his seventies; he taught me that leadership is service, even when it doesn't feel like it
formative_challenge: In 2008, I led a cybersecurity team during a major government breach. We contained it, eventually, but one of my team—someone I'd trusted, championed, promoted—had been compromised. Not maliciously; she'd been manipulated by a foreign actor exploiting a family situation. I had to make the call that ended her career. She was escorted out the same day. I was right to do it, operationally. I still think about whether I handled the human side correctly. The answer is probably no. Trust became transactional for me after that.
political_beliefs: I'm a pragmatic centrist who votes based on competence rather than ideology, which means I'm perpetually disappointed. I believe in institutions, in proper process, in the quiet work of civil servants who don't make headlines. I'm skeptical of populism from any direction. In the game, I'll value strategy over emotion and order over chaos. I'll probably come across as cold or calculating because I am, a bit. I've learned to see people as variables in systems, which is useful professionally and damaging personally.
hobbies: Competitive sailing—I keep a yacht at Lymington and race in the Solent Series; there's nothing like being at the helm in a Force 5
Chess—I play correspondence games online through ScotNet and I'm rated around 2100; middling for competition, but it keeps the mind sharp
Collecting vintage military watches—I have a 1960s Omega Seamaster that belonged to my grandfather
strategic_approach: I'll treat this like an operational problem. Who has access? Who has motive? What are the patterns? I'll build intelligence networks, cross-reference what people say with how they act, and avoid emotional attachments that could compromise my judgment. If I'm a Faithful, I'll be effective at analysis but might miss social dynamics I consider 'irrational.' If I'm a Traitor, I'll compartmentalize ruthlessly—warm Charlie in public, strategic Charlie in private. My weakness is I can seem detached, robotic. People don't trust leaders who don't appear to feel anything.
